Waypoints.Description: In this Story, we are giving a tour of a unique sample of a NF1 mut, BRAF wt melanoma, which contains multiple fields of disease progression. From left to right, the regions highlighted show melanoma in situ, polypoid exophytic tumor growth, and regions of invasive melanoma. Throughout this Story, we present findings from our paper that describe and deeply characterize these unique regions by CyCIF, single-cell profiling, and microregional sequencing. Each of these heterogeneous areas are comprised of different cell types ranging from keratinocytes (Pan-CK+) and melanocytes (SOX10+) to various subsets of immune (CD3d+ T cells, CD11C+ and/or CD163+ myeloid cells) and stromal cells, which we will discuss and highlight later.
Waypoints.Name: Overview of sample MEL1-F8

Waypoints.Description: A closer look of the Melanoma In Situ (MIS) region illustrates the horizontal axis of melanoma regression from left to right with a decreasing number of melanocytes (SOX10+, green) in the Pan-CK (pan Cytokeratin)+ epidermis. The region highlighted in the left contains MIS with dermal macrophages and a moderate T cell (CD3d+) infiltration in the adjacent dermal region. The MIS region with inflammatory regression in the middle is characterized by the presence and abundance of T cells and myeloid cells (CD11c+ and/or CD163+) in the dermal field which directly abuts epidermis. Notably, a majority of the T cells infiltrating into epidermis within this region are exhausted (PD1+ TIM3+ and/or LAG3+; data shown in Waypoint #13). The terminal regression of melanoma does not contain any melanocytes, but harbors a dense infiltrate of T cells.
Waypoints.Name: Melanoma in Situ

Waypoints.Description: The invasive melanoma region has an abundance of SOX10+ tumor cells invading into the dermis (highlighted with arrows). The adjacent stroma harbors dense infiltrates of T cells (CD3d+) and dendritic cells (CD11C+). The endothelial cells (CD31+) and myofibroblasts (aSMA+) are forming vascular structures.
Waypoints.Name: Invasive melanoma

Waypoints.Description: The exophytic tumor component has dense areas of SOX10+ tumor cells. CD11C+ myeloid cells (magenta) line the vascular structures (CD31+, red), but can also be seen infiltrating the tumor region (arrows). The CD3+ T cells (yellow) are however restricted to the regions surrounding the vasculature and are being excluded from the tumor region.
Waypoints.Name: Exophytic tumor growth

Waypoints.Description: Immune active and suppressive regions can exist close to one another in the same sample. The left-hand box is a region of inflammatory regression and the right-hand box is the stroma adjacent to the invasive boundary. Although both of these regions contain abundant exhausted T cells, the outcome of the immune editing process depends on their interactions with other neighboring stromal cells and their proximity to tumor cells (i.e. different immune editing in the melanoma in situ (MIS) versus invasive melanoma (IM); leading to tumor regression in the MIS and the formation of a resulting protective tumor microenvironment in the IM).
Waypoints.Name: Fields of active immune editing

Waypoints.Description: Here we highlight a niche of PDL1 positive myeloid cells which lines the invasive boundary as an immune suppressive barrier. Regulatory T cells were uniformly distributed within the different regions of the tumor, however, the invasive boundary was the only region where an interaction between regulatory T cells and exhausted T cells was observed.
Waypoints.Name: Immune suppression

Waypoints.Description: This macro-level view of the entire specimen illustrates the single-cell phenotyping performed for quantification. After single-cell segmentation, each individual cell was assigned into a specific phenotypic category. Here, the broad phenotypic categories are highlighted with colored segmentation masks: tumor (green), T cells (cyan), myeloid cells (yellow) and vasculature (red).
Waypoints.Name: Single-cell segmentation and phenotyping

Waypoints.Description: This view represents the single-cell phenotyping within the invasive melanoma region. The broad phenotypes highlighted here are tumor (green), T cells (cyan), myeloid cells (yellow) and vasculature (red). Identifying specific phenotypes allows us to study cell-to-cell interactions and the tissue structure in great detail.
Waypoints.Name: Detailed cell phenotyping in the invasive region

Waypoints.Description: To study similarities and differences among SOX10+ tumor cells, we performed unsupervised clustering using 30 different CyCIF markers following single-cell phenotyping. This yielded six clusters (T1-4, T5a and T5b), which were differentiated by the expression of melanoma associated markers. The violin plot below illustrates the marker expression as well as the percentage of total tumor cells that make up each tumor cell cluster. The spatial information linked to the single-cell data allowed us to observe that a proportion of the clusters were spatially organized.
Waypoints.Name: Intratumor heterogeneity

Waypoints.Description: One of the spatially restricted clusters (cluster T5b) was characterized by Cyclin D1+ tumor cells, which primarily surrounded perivascular spaces within the exophytic tumor region. These cells had a distinct spindle-like morphology with lengthened nuclei (arrows).
Waypoints.Name: Spatially restricted tumor states I

Waypoints.Description: Another spatially restricted cluster (T5a) had SOX10+ tumor cells expressing high levels of major histocompatibility complex-II (MHC-II). Although MHC-II is primarily expressed on antigen presenting immune cells, exposure to interferon gamma (IFNy) can lead to up-regulation of MHC-II also in tumor cells. These MHC-II+ cells were enriched at the leading edge of the invasive melanoma adjacent to the stroma (arrow) suggesting signals from the tumor microenvironment can drive tumor heterogeneity. We observed an up-regulation of interferon-gamma in the invasive boundary of the invasive melanoma via microregional transcriptomics (inset top). Additionally, neighborhood analysis revealed there was a significant co-occurrence between PDL1+ macrophages and cells in cluster T5a (inset bottom).
Waypoints.Name: Spatially restricted tumor states II

Waypoints.Description: When evaluating the immune subsets in the various stages of melanoma progression, we observed that T cells were abundant in the stromal region adjacent to the invasive tumor boundary -- this is what we refer to as the brisk tumor infiltrating lymphocyte (bTIL) region outlined in the box. Although a minor proportion of T cells are infiltrating the tumor region (arrows), the majority of T cells are restricted to the stroma. Here, the majority of CD8+ T cells (refered to as CTLs) are either activated (PD1+) or exhausted (PD1+ TIM3+ and/or LAG3+). TIM3+ CD8- cells were further identified as CD11C+ dendritic cells (data not shown). Microregional transcriptomics highlights that genes related to T cell exhaustion were up-regulated within the bTIL region in comparison to the exophytic melanoma (EM) region (inset).
Waypoints.Name: T cell exhaustion in the invasive region

Waypoints.Description: In this sample, the cytotoxic CD8+ T cells (white) that did not express any exhaustion markers (arrow) were in the minority (0.1% of all cells). However, they were notably enriched in the dermal region of MIS with inflammatory regression (highlighted with a rectangle and seen in the inset). We also observed epidermal infiltration of exhausted T cells (TIM3+: red, and/or LAG3+: magenta) within this specific region.
Waypoints.Name: Cytotoxic T cell enrichment in the region of inflammatory regression

Waypoints.Description: The spatial cell to cell proximity analysis revealed significant co-localization of CD11C+ PD-L1+ dendritic cells (orange) and terminally exhausted TIM3+ T cells (cyan), suggesting PDL1-PD1 ligand-receptor interactions between these cell types and that PDL1+ myeloid cells are one major driver of immune suppression within melanoma tumor microenvironment.
Waypoints.Name: Identification and characterization of cell to cell interactions
